headline: Expression peaks during early intracellular infection stages with strong female-specific upregulation
one_paragraph_summary:
This gene exhibits stage-specific expression patterns in Cryptosporidium parvum with several key characteristics:
  • Peak expression occurs 12-24 hours post-infection during early intracellular stages, with up to 24-fold higher expression compared to oocysts
  • Dramatic upregulation in female stages in vivo (682 TPM, 93rd percentile), suggesting important roles in sexual development
  • Strong antisense transcription activity, indicating potential regulatory functions through natural antisense transcripts
  • Minimal expression in sporozoites but consistent high expression during active infection
The temporal and stage-specific expression patterns suggest this gene plays critical roles in establishing intracellular infection and sexual differentiation, potentially functioning as both a protein-coding gene and regulatory RNA through its antisense activity.

topics.headline: Early intracellular infection shows dramatic temporal upregulation
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression increases dramatically from 2-12 hours post-infection, reaching peak levels at 12-24 hours with 20-24 fold higher expression compared to dormant oocysts, indicating critical roles in establishing intracellular infection.

topics.headline: Sexual development stages exhibit highest expression levels
topics.one_sentence_summary: Female stages in vivo show the highest expression (682 TPM, 93rd percentile) across all lifecycle stages, with moderate expression during culture development and minimal expression in sporozoites.

topics.headline: Strong antisense transcription suggests regulatory function
topics.one_sentence_summary: Dramatically higher antisense compared to sense strand expression during infection indicates this locus produces natural antisense transcripts that may regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally.
